issue.title: Implement a Joint normal form funsor
issue.body:
Resolves #68 
Based on #65 

This implements a `Joint` funsor incorporating a single `Number`/`Tensor`, a single `Gaussian` (or `Number(0)` if not needed), and zero or more `Delta`s. See #68 for motivation.

Pyro handles distributions of a few different forms. With `num_particles=1` Pyro handles a product-of-deltas (i.e. a single sample at each site):
```py
Finitary(ops.add, (Delta(...), ..., Delta(...)))  # product in log-space
```
The same representation works for vectorized particles, since the reduction doesn't happen until the end, so each `Delta` can carry an extra `particles` input dim.

`TraceEnum_ELBO` in Pyro supports lazy discrete samples, which would be represented as a product of a single Tensor (for all enumerated sites) and finitely many Deltas for sampled sites.
```py
Finitary(ops.add, (Tensor(...), Delta(...), Delta(...), ..., Delta(...)))
```
Note 1. `JointNormalForm` is intended as the interpreter during an optimized variable elimination schedule, therefore we store a single treewidth-sized `Tensor` rather than separate factors.
Note 2. unless we support direct products #70, plates are handled outside of `JointNormalForm`.

This PR builds on the generalized Gaussian #37 which combines a joint distribution among multiple Categorical, Normal, and MultivariateNormal random variables, which can all be sampled lazily. Thus the initial representation in Funsor is
```py
Finitary(ops.add, (Delta(...), ..., Delta(...), Tensor(...), Gaussian(...)))
```

## Tasks
- [x] add tests for `Joint` ops
- [x] add tests for promotion to `Joint`

body: Looking at the Toeplitz and Kronecker `LazyTensor`s in GPyTorch might be helpful too.

issue.title: Unify multilinear operations

milestone.title: Initial release
milestone.description: Working implementations of the examples in the design doc as well as any necessary infrastructure

issue.body:
Funsor currently contains many different representations of multilinear operations (e.g. `Joint`, `Affine`, `Finitary`, `Contract`, `Integrate`, `Binary`, `Reduce`, `einsum`, `sum_product`, ...) that approximately duplicate lots of logic and don't always play well together.

In a sequence of refactoring PRs, I would like to unify most of the duplicated linear algebra or normalization logic in the codebase while preserving all existing test cases and computational properties.  Specifically, I would like to:
1. #157 Add a `Contraction` normal form representing finitary sum-product operations with eager definitions implemented entirely in terms of unary and binary sum-product operations, and a `normalize` interpretation putting multilinear expressions into a DNF-like normal form
2. #157 Insert `normalize` as the underlying interpretation to which `eager` defaults, displacing `reflect` (optionally at first, using an environment variable as with the changes in #149).
3. #173 Remove `Affine` and replace with `Contraction` while preserving all existing test cases and functionality
4. #165 Simplify the optimizer by removing `Finitary`, `Contract`, `funsor.contract._simplify_contract`, and the `associate`, `distribute` and `desugar` interpretations used internally, and making it work with `normalize` and `Contraction`s directly
5. #169 Simplify `Integrate` by removing the duplicate functionality of `funsor.integrate._simplify_integrate`
6. #169 Remove `Joint` and replace with `Contraction` and `MultiDelta` while preserving all `Joint` test cases and computational properties.  This will also further simplify `eager`, since most of `Joint`'s functionality is already contained in the first PR.
7. #169 Remove `Delta` entirely in favor of `MultiDelta` so that deltas are closed under addition/logaddexp like `Gaussian` and `Tensor`
10. Troubleshoot performance issues related to interleaved interpreters (see `test_gaussian.py::test_eager_subs`, `test_samplers.py::test_gaussian_distribution`, `test_terms.py::test_reduce_subset` for cases of severe slowdowns)
8. Simplify `eager` by removing all purely algebraic computations from `eager` that are now handled by `normalize`, such as `funsor.terms.eager.distribute_binary_reduce_other`, and narrowing the focus of `eager` to only performing eager computations that actually invoke backend ops.
9. Rename `Contraction` -> `Contract`, `MultiDelta` -> `Empirical`, remove `Delta` entirely, move patterns in `joint.py` to `integrate.py`
11. Make optimization the default (merge `eager_contraction_generic_tuple` and the optimizer generic `Contraction` pattern from #165 )

More speculative: can we naturally and generically handle plate and scan dimensions #70 in `normalize`?

Plan for code review/merging:
1. Finish PRs for steps 1-6 above
2. Review and merge those PRs into #157, in descending order (i.e. 3, 4, 5, 6, 7)
3. Merge the final version of #157 into `master`
4. Make normalization the default and address steps 8-10 in cleanup PRs

Non-goals:
- I do not plan to replace or remove `Unary`, `Binary`, `Integrate`, or `Reduce`
- I do not plan to change any `eager` definitions or require them to be written in terms of `Contraction`.  `normalize` should not be proscriptive about the specification of eager operations.

issue.title: Implement more advanced indexing operations
issue.body:
#161 and related efforts #70 #177 will require additional advanced indexing functionality.
- [x] #205 Implement `Slice` term that can be used instead of `arange` for affine indexing operations that do not trigger memory copies
- [x] #206 Implement `Cat` term backed by `torch.cat` for `Gaussian`, `Tensor`, `Delta`/`Joint`
- [x] Implement interpretation of `Stack` backed by `torch.stack` for `Tensor`
- [x] #279 Update dependent type inference for `arange` to be like [this change](https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/pull/161/files#diff-ef277868cc1b65f45c112feff8cf65d7R150) in #161 so that it has the right inputs and outputs
- [ ] Implement interpretation of `Stack` backed by `torch.stack` for `Gaussian`, `Delta`, `GaussianMixture`

issue.title: Implement log-time sequential sum product function
issue.body:
Addresses #70 #177
This ports Pyro's algorithm from https://github.com/pyro-ppl/pyro/pull/1958 to funsor.
Pair coded with @eb8680 

## Tested
- added tests with `Tensor` contraction.

## Triaged
- make a `Slice` funsor
- implement `Cat` for `Gaussian`s and `Joint`s.

issue.title: Implement log-time Markov sum product algorithm
issue.body:
Addresses #70 #177
Pair coded with @eb8680 

This aims to generalize `sequential_sum_product()` from simple contractions to arbitrary contractions with different window size. This aims to be maximally general and should be able to be integrated into the TVE algorithm `partial_sum_product()` (as in the [convolve-method branch](https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/compare/convolve-method?expand=1)).

## Design Questions
- [ ] What problem class should we address? E.g. should this assume that the components have already been decomposed by a connected components algorithm? I've started to enumerate test cases, and I think we should spend a many hours whiteboarding examples to understand the problem class (as we did with TVE).
- [ ] How can we pass around the metadata of time lags? This PR attempts to do so via name mangling of `.inputs.keys()`, but that approach won't currently work because alpha binding mangles names in a different way. Indeed the alpha mangling appears to thwart other nearby designs such as passing in a side-information dict indicating which names correspond to which lags. One possible solution is to make alpha renaming less intrusive. @eb8680 can you think about possible solutions?

issue.title: Implement DiscreteHMM as a FunsorDistributions
issue.body:
Addresses #177 

This adds a new module funsor.pyro.hmm implementing `DiscreteHMM`, including support for `MaskedDistribution` and `.expand()` so it can be used in pyro/examples/hmm.py.

This is a first step intended to create passing tests. Further refactorings in #177 should keep these tests passing without modification. In particular this PR hand-codes math that will later be moved into an optimization strategy.

## Tested
- added lots of comparison with `pyro.distributions.DiscreteHMM` for different batch shapes and observation distributions
- added a unit test for `MaskedDistribution`
- verified that `funsor.pyro.DiscreteHMM` works in pyro/examples/hmm.py.
  Profiling results for `python -O pyro/examples/hmm.py -m 7 -n 100`
  **Pyro:**   6.1 sec
  **Funsor:** 10.9 sec

issue.title: Project: Implement time series models usable in Pyro

milestone.title: Initial release
milestone.description: Working implementations of the examples in the design doc as well as any necessary infrastructure

issue.body:
This issue plans PRs required to implement Bayesian filtering models in funsor that can then be used within Pyro models. We'd like to include a number of these in the initial release.

## Low level algorithms and math
- [x] #161  Implement `sequential_sum_product()` for discrete HMMs
- [x] #176 Implement `sequential_sum_product()` for Gaussian HMMs
- [x] #183 Support multiple variables in `sequential_sum_product()`
- [x] #173 Support multivariate linear pattern matching for linear-Gaussian filtering
- [x] #178 Implement partial substitution of Gaussian funsors 
- [x] #186 #184 Support rank-deficient operands in Gaussians ops
- ~~Implement a "Gaussian GEMM" that avoids the broadcast-multiply-reduce pattern (see `pyro.ops.gaussian.gaussian_tensordot()` https://github.com/pyro-ppl/pyro/pull/1980)~~ moved to https://github.com/pyro-ppl/funsor/issues/238
- ~~#167 Implement a `markov_sum_product()` for structured HMMs with arbitrary time window~~

## High level components
- [x] #170 Implement a `FunsorDistribution` wrapper to embed funsor distributions in Pyro
- [x] #174 #175 Implement funsor-pyro conversion functions
- [x] #205 Promote `funsor.sum_product.Slice` from an ad-hoc function to a `Funsor`
- [x] #206 Implement `eager_cat` for `Tensor`, `Gaussian`, `Joint` (cross listed in #162)
- ~~#70 Add a `Markov` or `Convolve` funsor~~

## Models as distributions
- [x] #171 Implement `DiscreteHMM` as a `FunsorDistribution`
- [x] #179 Implement a `GaussianMRF`
- [x] #185 Implement a `GaussianHMM`
- ~~#182 Implement a `GaussianDiscreteMRF`~~
- ~~#180 Implement a switching linear dynamical system MRF~~
- [x]  #187 Implement a switching linear dynamical system HMM
- ~~Implement a Tensor Monte Carlo smoothing `FunsorDistribution`~~
